name: hooper

attributes.attribute: helpful but sometimes vindictive Cornish weather spirit
dense fog that blocked out all vision
cloudy curtain from which a central light shone
appearance was invariably followed by fierce storms
tells of a sailor who jeered at the hooper and took out his crew despite the warning
passed into the gloom and was never seen again

sources: Monaghan, Patricia. The Encyclopedia of Celtic Mythology and Folklore. Checkmark Books, 2008.
text: A figure of Cornish folklore, the hooper or hooter, is a weather spirit that can be helpful, but also has a vindictive streak similar to the Scottish Gray Man. The hooper appears as a dense fog or a cloudy curtain with a central light, completely obstructing all visibility. Those who witness the hooper are warned to stay ashore, as the appearance of the hooper is always followed by violent storms. According to legend, a sailor who scoffed at the hooper and continued on with their crew disappeared into the darkness and was never seen again.
